title: My Honest Take on Pear Tallow Balm (And Why It Beat My Expensive Creams)
body:
Okay so. It’s winter. My skin is basically a dried-up leaf. I was using this fancy cream from Sephora, the La Mer one my sister swore by. A hundred and something dollars. For what. My face still felt tight. Like, an hour after putting it on. Tight and weird. I’d look in the mirror at like 3 PM and my cheeks looked… parched. It was stupid. I was sitting there in my kitchen, wearing these gross fleece socks, staring at this tiny jar thinking this is a scam. A whole scam.

Then I kept seeing stuff about tallow balm. Beef fat. For your face. I was like, you have got to be kidding me. But my hands were so bad. Cracking by my thumbs. Nothing worked. Not the O’Keeffe’s Working Hands, not the Neutrogena Norwegian Formula, nothing. I was desperate. So I ordered this Whipped Tallow Balm in Pear from some little Etsy shop. Figured if it was gross I’d just use it on my heels or something.

It showed up on a Tuesday. I think it was Tuesday. The mail comes late now.

## How Beef Tallow for Skin Actually Makes Sense (To Me Now)

I opened the jar. First thought: it doesn’t look like beef fat. It’s whipped. Like really thick frosting. I poked it. It was cold from the mailbox. Smelled like… pear? But not like candy. Not like the Jergens lotion. More like if you had a real pear and some grass. I don’t know. It’s hard. It’s a subtle sweetness. Gentle. I was skeptical but my knuckles were literally bleeding so I scooped a tiny bit.

Rubbed it on the back of my hand. It melted. Like, immediately. Went from this firm balm to almost nothing. My skin just drank it. No greasy film. No shiny residue. It was just… gone. And my skin felt like skin. Not like plastic-wrapped skin. Not like slippery skin. Just normal. But hydrated. I sat there for a minute just bending my fingers. No pulling. No cracking feeling.

Wait, where was I going with this. Right. Why it works. I looked it up after because I was confused. Beef tallow, especially from grass-fed cows, is apparently really similar to the oils our own skin makes. The sebum stuff. So it doesn’t just sit on top like most store stuff—it sinks in. Mimics it. My fancy La Mer cream was probably fighting my skin. This tallow balm was like, oh hey, we speak the same language. Made in France, which felt fancy for beef fat, but whatever.

## What This Pear Tallow Balm Actually Does (For My Weird Skin)

So I got brave. Used it on my face. I have this combo skin that’s dry but also gets weird bumps. Sensitive. Rosacea maybe. My dermatologist gave me this prescription cream that cost $80 and made me peel. It was a whole thing.

I washed my face, patted it dry, and used a tiny dab of the tallow. Smaller than a pea. Rubbed my palms together and just pressed it on. Didn’t drag. It felt… rich. But not heavy. My skin felt calm. Not instantly moisturized, but like it was being fed. Does that make sense? Probably not.

The next morning was the real test. Usually I wake up and my T-zone is an oil slick but my cheeks are desert. That morning was different. My skin just looked even. Not oily. Not dry. Just balanced. And soft. But not “product” soft. I kept touching my face which you’re not supposed to do. I couldn’t help it.

I started using it every night. On my hands, my elbows, this dry patch on my shin. My elbows haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid. I’m not kidding. It’s been a few weeks now. The jar is maybe half gone? I use it sparingly. A little goes a seriously long way.

## My Skin After Switching From Commercial Stuff

The big difference, the real one, isn’t a single moment. It’s that I just stopped thinking about my skin. It wasn’t a problem anymore. I wasn’t constantly reapplying lotion. I wasn’t avoiding certain fabrics because my hands would snag. I wasn’t looking in every reflective surface to check for flakiness.

I was at the grocery store the other day and I saw the aisle. The skincare aisle. Miles of plastic bottles with promises. “72-hour hydration!” “Clinical strength!” “Dermatologist tested!” I just walked past. I didn’t need any of it. I had my little jar of whipped beef fat at home. And it worked better than all of that.

It’s funny. We’re trained to think natural vs commercial skincare means the natural stuff is weak. Less effective. You need the lab-made chemicals to really fix something. But this is the opposite. This is the most basic, ancient ingredient possible. And it’s fixing the problems the billion-dollar labs couldn’t.

My sister came over last week, the La Mer one. She saw the jar on my bathroom counter. “What’s this?” I told her. She made a face. “You put cow fat on your face?” I just said, “Feel my cheek.” She did. She was quiet for a second. “What is that?” I told her again. She ordered a jar that night. I’m not even joking.

## Would I Buy This Pear Tallow Balm Again?

Yeah. I already did. I got a second jar last week because I was getting low and I panicked a little. I don’t want to run out. I use it every single day. My nighttime routine is wash face, tallow balm, done. My morning routine is splash water, maybe a tiny bit more if it’s really cold out, done.

It’s not magic. It won’t make you look 20 again. But if your skin is angry, or dry, or sensitive, or just confused… it might help it chill out. It helped mine. My skin just feels healthy now. Not “product healthy.” Actually healthy.

I got mine from this Etsy shop, [Shop Name]. The shipping was fast. Jar was cute. Simple. No crazy packaging. It just showed up and did its job.

Anyway. If you’re tired of spending a fortune on creams that don’t work, maybe give tallow a shot. It sounds weird. It is weird. But it works. My skin’s happy. I’m happy. That’s all I wanted.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, for me it is. Way better than anything else I’ve tried. Because it’s so close to our own skin oils, it absorbs properly. Doesn’t just coat the surface. My face actually drinks it up instead of rejecting it.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
I was worried about that. My skin clogs if you look at it wrong. But this hasn’t. At all. I think because it absorbs so deeply, it doesn’t just sit there and gunk things up. My bumpy texture actually got better.

**What does the Pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s light. Fresh. Not like a pear candle. More like the idea of a pear, with something clean and green underneath. It’s not strong. Fades pretty quick after you put it on. Just a subtle sweetness while you’re applying it.

So yeah. If your skin is being difficult this winter, might be worth a shot. I’m probably gonna order another one soon just to have as a backup.
